subject: Science
textbook: Science – Textbook for Class IX (Rationalised Edition)

chapters.title: Matter in Our Surroundings
topics: Definition of matter and classification based on physical nature
Characteristics of particles of matter
States of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Interconversion of states of matter
Effect of temperature and pressure on state
Evaporation and factors affecting evaporation
Role of evaporation in everyday life (cooling, sweating etc.)

notes.summary: This chapter introduces matter as anything that occupies space and has mass, explains its particle nature, and describes how matter exists and changes between different physical states.
key_points: Matter is made up of tiny particles that have space between them, move continuously, and attract each other.
Solids have fixed shape and volume, liquids have fixed volume but no fixed shape, and gases have neither fixed shape nor fixed volume.
Change of state (solid, liquid, gas) can be brought about by changing temperature or pressure, as in melting of ice or liquefaction of gases.
Latent heat is the heat supplied or removed during change of state without change in temperature.
Evaporation is the surface phenomenon of slow vaporisation and depends on temperature, surface area, humidity, and wind speed.

chapters.title: Is Matter Around Us Pure?
topics: Pure substances and mixtures
Types of mixtures: homogeneous and heterogeneous
Solutions, suspensions, and colloids
Concentration of solutions (qualitative idea)
Physical and chemical changes
Methods of separation of components of mixtures

notes.summary: The chapter explains that most substances around us are mixtures, compares types of mixtures and solutions, and describes common methods used to separate their components.
key_points: A pure substance has a fixed composition and sharp melting and boiling points, whereas mixtures contain more than one substance physically combined.
Solutions are homogeneous mixtures, while suspensions and colloids are heterogeneous with different particle sizes and visibility.
Physical changes affect the form of a substance without forming a new one, while chemical changes produce new substances with different properties.
Mixtures can be separated using methods like filtration, evaporation, distillation, decantation, chromatography, and centrifugation depending on particle properties.
Air, seawater, and many food items are common examples of mixtures encountered in daily life.

chapters.title: Atoms and Molecules
topics: Laws of chemical combination (law of conservation of mass, law of constant proportions)
Dalton’s atomic theory (basic postulates)
Concept of atom and molecule
Symbols of elements
Writing chemical formulae of simple compounds
Idea of mole and atomic/molecular mass (restricted to simple problems)

notes.summary: This chapter introduces the idea that matter is made of atoms and molecules, states basic laws of chemical combination, and shows how to write simple chemical formulae.
key_points: The law of conservation of mass states that mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction.
The law of constant proportions states that a chemical compound always contains the same elements in the same fixed ratio by mass.
Dalton proposed that atoms are indivisible particles of an element that participate in chemical reactions and combine in simple whole-number ratios.
Molecules are groups of two or more atoms chemically bonded together and can be of elements or compounds.
Chemical formulae represent the composition of compounds using symbols and valencies of constituent elements.

chapters.title: Structure of the Atom
topics: Discovery of subatomic particles: electron, proton, neutron
Thomson’s model of the atom
Rutherford’s alpha-particle scattering experiment and nuclear model
Bohr’s model of the atom (basic features)
Atomic number and mass number
Isotopes and isobars and their applications

notes.summary: The chapter traces how the model of the atom developed through experiments, describes subatomic particles, and introduces atomic number, mass number, isotopes, and isobars.
key_points: Cathode ray and canal ray experiments led to the discovery of negatively charged electrons and positively charged protons.
Thomson’s model pictured the atom as a positively charged sphere with electrons embedded in it like seeds in a watermelon.
Rutherford’s scattering experiment showed that most of the atom is empty space with a dense, positively charged nucleus at the centre.
Bohr proposed that electrons revolve in fixed orbits (shells) and each orbit has a fixed energy.
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different mass numbers, while isobars have the same mass number but belong to different elements.

chapters.title: The Fundamental Unit of Life
topics: Cell as the basic structural and functional unit of life
Discovery of the cell and cell theory
Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
Cell organelles: nucleus, mitochondria, plastids, vacuoles etc.
Plasma membrane and cell wall
Diffusion and osmosis (concept and simple examples)

notes.summary: This chapter describes the cell as the fundamental unit of life, outlines major cell structures and organelles, and explains how materials move across the cell membrane.
key_points: All living organisms are composed of cells, which may be unicellular or multicellular depending on the number of cells.
Prokaryotic cells lack a well-defined nucleus and membrane-bound organelles, while eukaryotic cells have them.
The plasma membrane is selectively permeable and controls the movement of substances into and out of the cell.
Cell organelles like mitochondria, plastids, endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi apparatus perform specific functions.
Diffusion and osmosis are passive processes through which molecules and water move along concentration gradients.

chapters.title: Tissues
topics: Definition of tissue
Plant tissues: meristematic and permanent tissues
Types of simple and complex permanent tissue
Animal tissues: epithelial, connective, muscular, nervous
Structure and function relationship in tissues
Examples of tissues in organs

notes.summary: The chapter explains how groups of similar cells form tissues, compares plant and animal tissues, and relates their structure to their functions.
key_points: A tissue is a group of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function.
Meristematic tissue in plants is responsible for growth, while permanent tissues perform support, transport, and storage functions.
Xylem and phloem are complex permanent tissues that transport water, minerals, and food in plants.
Animal tissues include epithelial (covering), connective (supporting and binding), muscular (movement), and nervous (control and coordination) tissues.
Different organs in plants and animals contain characteristic arrangements of tissues suited to their roles.

chapters.title: Motion
topics: Concepts of rest and motion
Distance and displacement
Speed and velocity
Average speed and average velocity
Acceleration and uniform/non-uniform motion
Distance–time and velocity–time graphs
Equations of uniformly accelerated motion (concept and use)

notes.summary: This chapter introduces basic terms used to describe motion and uses graphs and simple equations to relate distance, time, speed, and acceleration.
key_points: An object is in motion if its position changes with time relative to a chosen reference point.
Distance is the total path length travelled, while displacement is the shortest straight-line distance between initial and final positions with direction.
Speed is the rate of change of distance and velocity is the rate of change of displacement in a given direction.
Acceleration measures how quickly velocity changes with time and can be positive, negative, or zero.
Graphs and kinematic equations help to solve numerical problems involving uniformly accelerated motion.

chapters.title: Force and Laws of Motion
topics: Concept of force and its effects
Balanced and unbalanced forces
Newton’s first law of motion and inertia
Newton’s second law of motion and momentum
Newton’s third law of motion
Applications of laws of motion in daily life

notes.summary: The chapter develops the concept of force and momentum and states Newton’s three laws of motion with everyday examples and simple quantitative ideas.
key_points: A force can change the state of motion or shape of an object and may act as a contact or non-contact interaction.
Balanced forces do not change the state of motion, whereas unbalanced forces produce acceleration.
Newton’s first law states that a body remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced external force, introducing the idea of inertia.
Newton’s second law relates the net force on an object to the rate of change of momentum and gives the familiar relation F = ma for constant mass.
Newton’s third law states that every action has an equal and opposite reaction, which explains phenomena like walking or recoil of a gun.

chapters.title: Gravitation
topics: Universal law of gravitation (qualitative idea)
Free fall and acceleration due to gravity
Mass and weight and their difference
Thrust and pressure in fluids
Buoyancy and Archimedes’ principle
Relative density

notes.summary: This chapter describes gravitational attraction between masses, distinguishes mass from weight, and explains buoyancy and fluid pressure using Archimedes’ principle.
key_points: The universal law of gravitation states that every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force depending on their masses and distance between them.
Objects falling freely under gravity near Earth’s surface experience an almost constant acceleration called acceleration due to gravity.
Mass is the amount of matter in a body and remains constant, while weight is the gravitational force on it and can change with location.
Fluids exert pressure in all directions, leading to the upward buoyant force experienced by objects immersed in them.
Archimedes’ principle states that the buoyant force on a body equals the weight of the fluid displaced, which helps determine relative density.

chapters.title: Work and Energy
topics: Definition of work in physics
Positive, negative, and zero work
Concept of energy
Kinetic energy and potential energy
Law of conservation of energy
Power and commercial unit of energy (kilowatt-hour)

notes.summary: The chapter defines work and energy in scientific terms, relates different forms of energy, and introduces power and the law of conservation of energy.
key_points: Work is said to be done when a force acting on an object causes displacement in the direction of the force.
Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by a body due to its motion, while potential energy is due to its position or configuration.
The total mechanical energy of a system can transform between kinetic and potential forms without loss in ideal situations.
The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only converted from one form to another.
Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred, and electrical energy used in homes is often measured in kilowatt-hours.

chapters.title: Sound
topics: Production of sound by vibrating objects
Propagation of sound as longitudinal waves
Speed of sound in different media (qualitative idea)
Characteristics of sound: amplitude, frequency, time period
Pitch and loudness; audible and inaudible sounds
Reflection of sound and echo
Basics of noise, music, and noise pollution

notes.summary: This chapter introduces sound as a wave produced by vibrations, discusses its characteristics and hearing range, and explains echoes and noise pollution.
key_points: Sound is produced when objects vibrate and the vibrations are transferred through a medium as longitudinal waves of compressions and rarefactions.
The speed of sound is greatest in solids, less in liquids, and least in gases because particle spacing and interactions differ.
Frequency of vibration determines pitch, amplitude determines loudness, and the human ear hears roughly a limited frequency range.
Sound reflects from hard surfaces following laws similar to light, giving rise to echoes and useful applications like SONAR in advanced study.
Unwanted, loud, or irregular sound is called noise and long-term exposure can cause health problems, so noise pollution must be controlled.

chapters.title: Improvement in Food Resources
topics: Need to improve food resources
Crop variety improvement (breeding for better traits)
Crop production management: nutrient management, irrigation, cropping patterns
Manures, fertilisers, and organic farming
Crop protection management: pests, weeds, and diseases
Animal husbandry: cattle, poultry, fishery, bee-keeping etc.

notes.summary: The chapter explains how crop and animal productivity can be improved using better varieties, management practices, and protection measures to meet growing food demands.
key_points: Improvement in food resources aims to increase both quantity and quality of food for a growing population.
Crop variety improvement uses selection and breeding to develop plants with higher yield, disease resistance, and tolerance to stresses.
Nutrient management, proper irrigation, and planned cropping patterns like mixed and inter-cropping raise productivity and maintain soil health.
Pest and disease management uses mechanical, biological, and limited chemical methods to protect crops without excessive environmental harm.
Scientific animal husbandry practices improve milk, egg, meat, fish, and honey production while maintaining animal health and welfare.
